repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - First and Second series of
            Programmatic Labor Reform and Social Structural Adjustment
            Loans and a Third Labor Reform and Social Development Policy Loan

abstracts.cdata!:
This report describes the results of a
            series of three projects in the Republic of Colombia: First
            Programmatic Labor Reform and Social Structural Adjustment
            Loan (PLaRSSAL I), Second Programmatic Labor Reform and
            Social Structural Adjustment Loan (PLaRSSAL II), and the
            Third Labor Reform and Social Development Policy Loan
            (LaRSDPL III); together comprising a programmatic lending
            operation spanning the four years of the first Uribe
            administration. The overall outcome of these three projects
            is rated satisfactory, and the performance of the Bank and
            the Borrower is also rated as satisfactory. Lessons learned:
            constant engagement with the client is important via a rich
            technical dialogue and varied portfolio. The multi-sectoral
            PLaRSSAL program team worked with the Government of Colombia
            (GoC) in a wide range of lending and non-lending activities,
            which facilitated the preparation of the program in two key
            ways. First, the GoC and Bank teams developed a good working
            relationship over many years. Second, the Bank team, through
            this continued relationship was well versed in the
            objectives, strategies, results-management, and outputs of
            the social sectors, allowing for a greater focus on strategy
            and implementation in the development of the program. A
            commitment by the clients to implement a well-designed
            Government program. The national development plan defined
            each social institution's strategic objectives for the
            Uribe administration, thereby providing a base upon which to
            design the Bank's program. The social institutions were
            committed to implementing the strategies and meeting the
            quantifiable targets and saw the value added of Bank support
            in the design, implementation, and evaluation of the strategy.

9375193.trustfund:
TF033001-BURUNDI - PUBLIC EXPENDITURE,TF052528-PHRD-COLOMBIA: SECOND

9375193.majtheme: Human development,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Second Programmatic Labor Reform
            and Social Structural Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, achieved through
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            Lessons are suggested as follows. An emphasis on
            results-based management, involving clear and measurable
            indicators, and a focus on outputs and outcomes, rather than
            inputs and processes, is critical to performance monitoring,
            revealing the strengths and weaknesses of the program, and
            allowing for immediate corrections when the processes are
            not reaching the desired results. Focusing on program
            outcomes permits the inclusion of many sectors, which would
            be difficult to manage in a series of operations if the
            outcomes for each sector were not clearly defined and
            measurable. A rich program of investment Loans, sector
            studies, and adjustment loans in other sectors is necessary
            to fill-out the labor and social reform program. While the
            series of programmatic labor reform structural adjustment
            loans have successfully met their goals, the Government and
            the Bank team understand that they have a specific and
            limited role. Other complementary Bank instruments are
            necessary to efficiently support the Government's
            fulfillment of its development plan. Further lessons address
            the importance of a strong and sustained dialogue between
            the Bank and the Government, and, a strong coordinating role.

5318172.trustfund:
TF052528-PHRD-COLOMBIA: SECOND
            PROGRAMMATIC LABOR AND SOCIAL SECTOR REFORM LOAN
5318172.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Human development

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Second Programmatic Labor Reform
            and Social Structural Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Programmatic Labor Reform and
            Social Structural Adjustment Loan Project will support the
            Government's objectives, i.e., to: a) increase
            employment; b) raise human capital formation; and, c)
            strengthen social protection. These objectives will be
            achieved by supporting reform of the Government's labor
            regulations, and improved training schemes; by enforcing
            legislation, amending the regulations on the
            decentralization of education and health services, while
            introducing incentives to enhance, and measure quality. In
            addition, an integrated, and more efficient social
            protection system will be developed, and, institutions for
            regular impact evaluation, and public oversight of social
            protection programs will be established. The project will
            specifically focus on: greater labor demand via employer
            incentives, and reductions in legal barriers to employment;
            increased coverage, efficiency, and targeting of social
            protection programs; quality and coverage improvements in
            the education sector; and, impact evaluation and social
            oversight of major social programs. Notwithstanding, several
            risks were identified: the overall political context, namely
            the internal conflict, and violence associated with illegal
            drug activity, the fiscal pressures, external economic and
            political shocks, opposition by special interest groups, the
            financial viability of the health reform, and, the
            sustainability of reforms that incur costs in the short-run.
            However, throughout the reform process, several actions are
            being undertaken to mitigate these risks, that is, both the
            Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) loans,
            studies, and technical assistance support the health sector
            reform, and, provide further support via projects, technical
            assistance, and studies to measure the impacts of social
            programs, promote the result for better program design and
            management, and disseminate findings to the public to
            strengthen the citizen's support of the reform program.
